original_title: Liquid (Reversibly) Solidifies at Room Temperature, Gets Used for 3D Prints
original_content:
Researchers demonstrate sustainable 3D printing by using poly(N-isopropylacrylamide) solutions (PNIPAM), which speedily and reliably turn solid by undergoing a rapid phase change when in a salt solution.
This property has been used to 3D print objects by using a syringe tip as if it were a nozzle in a filament-based printer. As long as the liquid is being printed into contact with a salt solution, the result is a polymer that solidifies upon leaving the syringe.
Whats also interesting is that the process by which the PNIPAM-based solutions solidify is entirely reversible. Researchers demonstrate printing, breaking down, then re-printing, which is an awfully neat trick. Finally, by mixing different additives in with PNIPAM, one can obtain different properties in the final product. For example, researchers demonstrate making conductive prints by adding carbon nanotubes.
While weve seen the concept of printing with liquids by extruding them into a gel bath or similar approach, we havent seen a process that prides itself on being so reversible before. The research paper with all the details is available here, so check it out for all the details.
title: ポリマー溶液を使用した持続可能な3Dプリントの実演
body: PNIPAMを使用した持続可能な3Dプリントがデモされ、塩溶液中で急速な相転移を起こすことで迅速かつ確実に固体になる。注射器をフィラメントベースのプリンターのノズルのように使用することで3Dオブジェクトのプリントが可能になる。PNIPAM系の溶液が固化するプロセスは完全に可逆で、異なる添加剤を混ぜてさまざまな特性を得ることも可能。
titles: ポリマー溶液を使用した持続可能な3Dプリントの実演
塩水溶液による急速な相転移により3Dプリントを実現
多様な添加剤を用いてプリント物の異なる特性を得る方法
PNIPAM溶液を用いた印刷、分解、再印刷の逆過程の実演
3Dプリンターでノズルを使用せずにシリンジ先端を用いた印刷方法
